titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Michael Miran Papers, 1964-1965 and undated RL.11617
titlestmt.author: Laurin Penland

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-03-28 15:45:55 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

origination.label: source
origination.corpname: John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture

did.abstract: Includes Clippings, typescripts, newsletters, and flyers relating to the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) and to a presentation by Bob Moses in Long Beach, California on January 23, 1965. The papers were collected by Michael Miran, who was involved with SNCC in Long Beach. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Michael Miran is a resident of Rochester, New York.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Michael Miran papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2018 and 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Michael Miran Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Addition processed by Alice Poffinberger, March, 2019
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2018-0044, 2019-0020.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Clippings, typescripts, newsletters, and flyers relating to the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) and to a presentation by Bob Moses in Long Beach, California on January 23, 1965. Acquired as part of the John Hope Franklin Research Center for African and African American History and Culture.
